body.p:
I read every num-
ber of your valuable periodical with
pleasurable interest, your leaders
especially possess for me great
interest, I read and digest them
carefully and form judgement in
accordance as they impress or con-
vince my intellect.

The popular style in
which these articles are written is well
calculated to awaken thought and
their freedom from obstruse and
pedantic argument makes them ac
ceptable to the practical men who
compose the majority of your readers
and who have little time to devote
to the study of learned disquisitions.

There is one theme I am most
desirous you should at your earliest
leisure prepare an article upon
either for a leader or not as you
may please. It is respecting the faith
of the Israelite in the coming of a
personal messiah. I would

suggest your discuss the title for the
article “Belief in the coming of a personal
messiah” I would open the article
in something like the following language
“One of the cardinal principles of faith
of a true Israelite is a belief in a person-
-al messiah. It is one of the thirteen a fundamental articles
of our creed. It has been taught our
Jewish youth since in the past it has
been the accepted belief of all the great
Rabbis and learned teachers of Israel
which with a very few exceptions—and it is
so imbued into our Religion as to make
it one of its most vital parts the removal
or destruction of which would lead
to the dissolution of our Religion itself.

Taught Given in the Pentateuch taught
by the Prophets inculcated by the Rabbins
and received by the Jewish youth from
the beginning it has been and is still
one of the fundamental principles of our
faith and must continue to be so long
as Judaism is preserved in its pristine
purity and truth “&c &c or in similar
language—the construction of the above
being imperfect from the haste in
which I have written. After an ex-

position of this fundamental principle I would give
all the passages in the Pentateuch and Pro
-phets that have special reference to it and
cite in addition, all the ancient authorities
(Rabbis) that received and sustained it.

Nay I would prove it conclusively
by irrefutable quotations of those whose
authority it would be absurd to deny
or refute. Do you quite comprehend
my wishes? If so will you be kind
enough to accede to them and in doing
so pardon me for the apparent counsel
? I have so impudently volunteered.

My apology for this must be in
the awakened deep interest I have recently
taken in the subject. If a belief in the
coming of a personal messiah can be
proved to be correct based upon the re-
vealed word of God and those sages
who have interpreted his it—let it be
done now in as simple clear concise and
irrefutable manner as possible. Let
the article of faith be stated let the divine
passages be given and the Rabbinical
authorities cited so that there can be no
question of its truth. Dr M Kalisch of
London I see has recently published the
Book of Genesis after a translation from

the original Hebrew—nay the Volume published
contains the Hebrew text with a translation
by Dr K and a full commentary illustra
ting the context, accompanied by philologi-
-cal remarks and concluding with a sum-
-mary of events. I have not of course seen the
work as it has not yet crossed the Atlantic
(ie to my knowledge) it being published in London
where Dr K is a tutor in the family of Baron
Rostchild—but it strikes me as being just
what is needed and I sincerely hope five
years will not elapse before the entire
24 books will be similarly published. How
much I now wish you had delayed your publica
-tion a few years and then brought it out in this
manner. However you can still do a great
work by preparing a second volume to be
called a “key” which shall be a full
commentary &c &c. I intend writing you
again in a few days upon some other
important matters concerning our Religion
in the meanwhile I trust you will fully consider my request favorably

With great esteem Sincerely Yours
B F. Peixotto
